page.title: 08Downs People and Roadways
page.content: On the Downs are traces of Bronze Age Tumuli, defensive earthworks and field sustems and the ancient track of the South Downs Way. There is also a more recent Dewpond for watering sheep which used to graze on the Downs. Two roads parallel to the foot of the Downs are only a few hundred yards apart because of the 17th century decision by the owners of Parham Park to prevent the highway crossing their land by building a second road with a tollhouse which is still inhabited.The old gate into the park is still remembered in the name 'Crossgates' attached to a modern group of houses. Charles 11 must have passed along this road in his escape after the Battle of Worcester.
